title: 109_hr3672
content: The Act titled "TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005" allows for advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 authorizes advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006, extending activities through December 31, 2005. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 extends the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant Program through December 31, 2005, authorizing activities to continue in the same manner as fiscal year 2005. Appropriations are made for necessary funds, allowing grants and payments to be made through the first quarter of fiscal year 2006 at the same level as the first quarter of fiscal year 2005. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 extends the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant Program through December 31, 2005, with appropriations for necessary funds. Grants and payments can be made through the first quarter of fiscal year 2006 at the same level as fiscal year 2005. Amendments are made for population increases in certain states and the contingency fund. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act, extending the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant Program through December 31, 2005. Changes include adjustments for population increases in certain states, the contingency fund, and maintenance of effort requirements. The National Random Sample Study of Child Welfare and Child Welfare Waiver Authority is extended through December 31, 2005, with amendments to the Social Security Act. Maintenance of effort requirements are adjusted for 2006 and 2007. The National Random Sample Study of Child Welfare and Child Welfare Waiver Authority is extended through December 31, 2005, with adjustments to the Social Security Act. Funding is appropriated for activities authorized for fiscal year 2005, with grants and payments allowed through the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. Reimbursement of states for TANF benefits provided to assist families affected by Hurricane Katrina from other states. Beginning with the enactment of this Act until August 31, 2006, a State qualifies as needy if it has provided short-term, nonrecurring cash benefits to families affected by Hurricane Katrina in another State declared a disaster area. The State qualifies as needy if short-term, nonrecurring cash benefits have been provided to families affected by Hurricane Katrina in another State declared a disaster area, and the family is not receiving cash benefits from any other State program funded under Title IV of the Social Security Act. The State qualifies as needy if short-term, nonrecurring cash benefits have been provided to families affected by Hurricane Katrina in another State declared a disaster area, and the family is not receiving cash benefits from any other State program funded under Title IV of the Social Security Act. The total amount paid to a needy State shall not exceed the total amount of cash benefits provided. The total amount paid to a needy State under this section shall not exceed the cash benefits provided to families affected by Hurricane Katrina. No State match is required for payments made under this section. SEC. 4. AVAILABILITY OF ADDITIONAL TANF FUNDS FOR HURRICANE-DAMAGED STATES. Beginning with the enactment of this Act until the end of fiscal year 2006, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama are eligible for loans under the Social Security Act. The total loan amount for these states cannot exceed 20 percent of the State family assistance grant for fiscal year 2006. Additionally, loans made to these states may be forgiven. The cumulative dollar amount of loans to Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama under the Social Security Act cannot exceed 20% of the State family assistance grant for fiscal year 2006. Loans made to these states may be forgiven. SEC. 5 allows States or tribes to use TANF funds to support needy families affected by Hurricane Katrina without fiscal year limitation. SEC. 6 states that work requirements and time limits under the TANF program are not triggered by families receiving temporary TANF benefits due to the hurricane. SEC. 6 exempts families affected by Hurricane Katrina from work requirements and time limits under the TANF program if they receive temporary benefits. SEC. 7 waives TANF penalties in hurricane-damaged states. SEC. 7 waives TANF penalties in hurricane-damaged states of Louisiana, Mississippi, or Alabama for non-compliance with certain provisions due to Hurricane Katrina or state's efforts to assist victims. Each amount provided in this Act is designated as an emergency requirement pursuant to section 402 of H. Con. Res. 95 (109th Congress).
